pr_title: [KEYCLOAK-11621] Allow user creation via group MANAGE_MEMBERS and MANAGE_MEMBERSHIP permissions (Admin API)

timeline.bodyText: This is strange, what's the difference between requireManageMembers and requireManageMembership?
timeline.author: stianst

replies.bodyText:
My understanding is the following:

MANAGE_MEMBERS_SCOPE: allowing an admin to manage users, i.e. create, update and delete users
MANAGE_MEMBERSHIP_SCOPE: allowing an admin to manage groups membership for a specific user

So, when creating a new user part of one or more groups, we need both permissions IMO. Let me know your thoughts.
replies.author: clementcur

timeline.bodyText: I think better is a 400 response.
timeline.author: pedroigor

replies.bodyText: yeah, makes sense - will update the PR then

timeline.message:
Cleaned imports

made sure explicit imports are used
removed unsed import

[KEYCLOAK-11621] Added ability to create users within a permitted group via Admin API

Problem:
Using fine-grained admin permissions on groups, it is not permitted to create new users
within a group.

Cause:
The POST /{realm}/users API does not check permission for each group part of the new
user representation

Solution:
- Change access logic for POST /{realm}/users to require MANAGE_MEMBERS and
MANAGE_MEMBERSHIP permissions on each of the incoming groups

Tests:
Manual API testing performed:
  1. admin user from master realm:
    - POST /{realm}/users without groups                  => HTTP 201 user created
    - POST /{realm}/users with groups                     => HTTP 201 user created
  2. user with MANAGE_MEMBERS & MANAGE_MEMBERSHIP permissions on group1
    - POST /{realm}/users without groups                  => HTTP 403 user NOT created
    - POST /{realm}/users with group1                     => HTTP 201 user created
    - POST /{realm}/users with group1 & group2            => HTTP 403 user NOT created
    - POST /{realm}/users with group1 & wrong group ID    => HTTP 400 user NOT created
  3. user with MANAGE_MEMBERS permission on group1
    - POST /{realm}/users without groups                  => HTTP 403 user NOT created
    - POST /{realm}/users with group1                     => HTTP 403 user NOT created
    - POST /{realm}/users with group1 & group2            => HTTP 403 user NOT created
    - POST /{realm}/users with group1 & wrong group ID    => HTTP 400 user NOT created

timeline.bodyText:
I did not catch this before, but I think we should first try to check requireManage and only in case we get an exception (lacking permission) we fallback to your changes that rely on the fine-grained permission.
The reason behind this comment is that we avoid people not using fine-grained permissions to not be impacted by the additional checks you are adding.
